candidates.title: Update to LLVM version 12
candidates.body:
This was pointed out in #67 as LLVM 10 is a couple releases back now, and some distros will make it easier to use a newer version. 

Small diff as everything built cleanly.

candidates.title: Replace custom arena with bumpalo
candidates.body:
I don't think I knew about bumpalo when I started this project, but there's basically no reason to use the old custom arena instead of this one.

This PR migrates the arena module from a custom implementation based on frozen vectors to a thin wrapper around bumpalo. It also changes the vectors to use bumpalo's custom Vec type, to move even more of the frontend data structures into the arena. Various cleanups along the way too.

candidates.title: Fast float
candidates.body:
This PR deletes the old implementation of eisel-lemeir and merges in the one from the new [fast-float](https://github.com/aldanor/fast-float-rust) library:

(_fast is the frawk-internal implementation, and _ff is the new fast-float implementation)

```
test runtime::float_parse::slow_path::bench::bench_strtod_long_fast    ... bench:         413 ns/iter (+/- 23)
test runtime::float_parse::slow_path::bench::bench_strtod_long_ff      ... bench:          53 ns/iter (+/- 25)
test runtime::float_parse::slow_path::bench::bench_strtod_medium_fast  ... bench:          20 ns/iter (+/- 5)
test runtime::float_parse::slow_path::bench::bench_strtod_medium_ff    ... bench:          25 ns/iter (+/- 6)
test runtime::float_parse::slow_path::bench::bench_strtod_short_fast   ... bench:          11 ns/iter (+/- 9)
test runtime::float_parse::slow_path::bench::bench_strtod_short_ff     ... bench:          10 ns/iter (+/- 1)
```

In the rudimentary benchmarks I had in the float_parse module, `fast_float` is far better on long strings (we fell back to libc, which is particularly slow) and seems to be slower -albiet within the margin of error- for short and medium strings (both of which are in the fast path for the algorithm. Performance aside, `fast_float` is far better tested than frawk's float_parse module.

I'll look around for any improvements to close the gap in the fast path, but I suspect the difference here may be in the noise.

candidates.title: Various cleanups
candidates.body: This change includes a number of small cleanups I was looking at, along with some test fixes in line with the new output formatting introduced in #44

candidates.title: Speed up column mutation
candidates.body:
This change includes a number of small improvements to speed up field mutation and `$0` reconstruction. 

One of these improvements was to change `Buf::slice_to_str` to prefer `Shared` strings rather than `Inline` strings. For strings that are only read once or twice, the extra `memcpy` of reading into an Inline string ends up being too much overhead. This change generates single-percentage-point decreases in runtime for some aggregation-heavy benchmarks, but I think the overall win for output-heavy benchmarks is enough to keep the change.

The other impact of this change was to make reference counting for many more strings in frawk scripts nontrivial. This revealed two separate bugs in the llvm and cranelift backends: both were `ref`-ing strings and maps too often, leading simple scripts to hold onto the entire input in memory. This took a while to track down, but this bug does appear to be fixed in this change.

candidates.title: Cranelift Backend
candidates.body:
This change adds a frawk backend that JITs machine code using cranelift. This is a large diff because I refactored a lot of the code in the LLVM module to live behind higher-level interfaces that we could implement in terms of either LLVM or cranelift. On top of that, I regenerated all of the benchmark numbers to include the cranelift backend.

Cranelift will be the new default backend for frawk. I'm hoping it will make frawk more accessible for people who do not want to install or build LLVM on their own.

candidates.title: Add new CLI-level tests in `tests` directory.
candidates.body:
This includes two files:

1. `nawk_p` which is a translation of the `p.` tests in the nawk repo
   into frawk.
2. `sort` which tests multithreaded and singlethreaded sorts for large
   inputs.

These tests all pass, but only with several modifications to frawk to
fix bugs uncovered by the tests.

candidates.title: Compile using stable
candidates.body:
I saw #25 , so I went ahead and took a pass. I added a default feature called `unstable`, so everything should work as is on nightly. On stable (`rustc 1.48.0 (7eac88abb 2020-11-16)` at the moment), this should now work:

```
cargo test --no-default-features --features use_jemalloc,allow_avx2,llvm_backend 2>&1 | tail
test runtime::utf8::x86::tests::test_utf8 ... ok
test runtime::writers::tests::basic_writing ... ok
test runtime::utf8::tests::test_partial ... ok
test runtime::writers::tests::reopen_named_file ... ok
test runtime::writers::tests::multithreaded_write ... ok
test runtime::utf8::tests::utf8_valid ... ok
test runtime::splitter::regex::tests::test_clipped_chunk_split_random ... ok

test result: ok. 194 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out

```

I excluded the `bench` tests when run on `stable`, which is why the number of tests is lower.

candidates.title: line-buffered stdout where appropriate
candidates.body:
Based on the suggestion in #18, this change adopts grep_cli to detect
when to line-buffer output, and adds support for line-buffering to the
`writers` module.

This change accomplishes this by:

* Plumbing through "flush on newlines" information into FileHandles for
  stdout, when stdout is a tty.
* Allowing write requests to trigger a flush of the underlying writer.

candidates.title: Upgrade to LLVM 10.
candidates.body: Tests pass on my Ubuntu and MacOS machines. No upgrades to the underlying LLVM calls were needed, though we'll eventually need to migrate away from MCJit.

candidates.title: Make UTF-8 Optional
candidates.body: This PR.removes the invariant that frawk strings can only contain valid UTF-8. It keeps the existing machinery for validating UTF-8, but places it behind a flag. Most of the internal string routines have been updated to operate on byte slices. Strings are (re)validated for UTF-8 where necessary (e.g. file opens, regex construction, printf, the first two of which are cached).
